melody.description: There is no melody or mood associated with this line, which may be because it is the preamble to the hymn, or is not meant to be read in any particular melody or mood

author.author: None
author.description: There is no author associated with this line, as it may be the preamble to the hymn

translation.text: By His Creative Power, God fashioned the creation.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:
Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: The King of kings Himself adminsters true justice.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

author.author: Guru Nanak Dev
author.description:

As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: The most sublime Word of the Guru's Teachings is always with us.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. translation.text: The wealth of the Lord's Name, the source of nectar, is easily acquired. ||1||

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਮਤ ਬਿਸਰਸਿ ਰੇ ਮਨ ਰਾਮ ਬੋਲਿ ॥

translation.text: So chant the Name of the Lord; do not forget it, O my mind.

transliteration.text: mat bisaras rē man rām bōl .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. This Raag encourages the mind to brush away its selfishness, just like spring-cleaning removes all the cobwebs and creates a fresh start. There are feelings of hope and expectation of a new beginning and the start of a new cycle. However, these emotions are not dependent on the physical change of the season, but are an encouragement of an internal effort to change.

Guru Nanak Dev Ji [1469 - 1539] was the first Guru of the Sikhs born in a village named Talwandi which is now called Nankana Sahib and is in Pakistan. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਅਪਰੰਪਰੁ ਅਗਮ ਅਗੋਚਰੁ ਗੁਰਮੁਖਿ ਹਰਿ ਆਪਿ ਤੁਲਾਏ ਅਤੁਲੁ ਤੋਲਿ ॥੧॥ ਰਹਾਉ ॥

translation.text: The Lord is Infinite, Inaccessible and Incomprehensible; His weight cannot be weighed, but He Himself allows the Gurmukh to weigh Him. ||1||Pause||

transliteration.text: aparanpar agam agōchar guramukh har āp tulāē atul tōl .1. rahāu .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: Your GurSikhs serve at the Guru's Feet.

text: ਗੁਰ ਸੇਵ ਤਰੇ ਤਜਿ ਮੇਰ ਤੋਰ ॥

translation.text: Serving the Guru, they are carried across; they have abandoned any distinction between 'mine' and 'yours'.

transliteration.text: gur sēv tarē taj mēr tōr .

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. As a child Guru Nanak spent most of his time in isolation and meditation. He slept only for a few hours, ate small quantities of food and spoke little.

One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

translation.text: The slanderous and greedy people are hard-hearted.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. One day he disappeared while having his morning bath and reappeared 3 days later and said: There is no Hindu and there is no Muslim. By saying this he meant that titles were meaningless because all of humanity is one and the light of God shines within everyone.

text: ਗੁਰ ਸੇਵ ਨ ਭਾਈ ਸਿ ਚੋਰ ਚੋਰ ॥੨॥

translation.text: Those who do not love to serve the Guru are the most thieving of thieves. ||2||

transliteration.text: gur sēv n bhāī s chōr chōr .2.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: When the Guru is pleased, He blesses the mortals with loving devotional worship of the Lord.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. text: ਗੁਰਿ ਤੁਠੈ ਪਾਈਐ ਹਰਿ ਮਹਲਿ ਠਾਉ ॥

translation.text: When the Guru is pleased, the mortal obtains a place in the Mansion of the Lord's Presence.

transliteration.text: gur tuthai pāīai har mahal thāu .

translation.text: So renounce slander, and awaken in devotional worship of the Lord.

melody.description: Basant denotes the changing of the season and the newness of spring. translation.text: Devotion to the Lord is wonderful; it comes through good karma and destiny. ||3||

translation.text: The Guru unites in union with the Lord, and grants the gift of the Name.

translation.text: The Guru loves His Sikhs, day and night.

text: ਫਲੁ ਨਾਮੁ ਪਰਾਪਤਿ ਗੁਰੁ ਤੁਸਿ ਦੇਇ ॥

translation.text: They obtain the fruit of the Naam, when the Guru's favor is bestowed.

transliteration.text: phal nām parāpat gur tus dēi .

translation.text: Says Nanak, those who receive it are very rare indeed. ||4||7||
